issues.description: The problem statement describes a class named 'Stock' (including UML and explicit text requiring a static Stock stock attribute), but the template and solution repositories provide a fully implemented class named 'Inventory' that contains the expected stock methods/field (add, take, findStockIngredient, addToStockIngredients, emptyStock). At the same time there is an (apparently empty) Stock.java file in both template and solution. This name/placement mismatch (Stock vs Inventory, plus an empty Stock.java) is a structural inconsistency that will confuse students about which class they should use or modify and may lead them to implement functionality in the wrong file or duplicate work.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the naming consistent across all artifacts. Either:
- Rename Inventory to Stock in the template and solution (move/merge Inventory implementation into Stock.java and remove the extra Inventory file), and update any references to Inventory accordingly; OR
- Update the problem statement and UML to refer to 'Inventory' instead of 'Stock' (and clarify that the static attribute is of type Inventory). Also remove or populate the empty Stock.java file to avoid confusion. Ensure the file students are expected to modify is the one described in the problem text.

issues.description: The problem statement describes and uses a class named 'Stock' (including in the UML and when describing the SealSaloon.stock attribute), but the provided template and the reference solution use a class named 'Inventory' that implements the expected stock behaviour. Additionally, the template contains an (empty) Stock.java file while Inventory.java contains the actual implementation. This mismatch (Stock vs Inventory) can confuse students when they try to map the problem description/UML to the starter code and the expected solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the name consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement and UML to refer to 'Inventory' instead of 'Stock', or (B) rename the Inventory class/file in the template and solution to 'Stock' (move/rename Inventory.java -> Stock.java and change the class name to Stock and all references). Also remove or populate the empty template Stock.java to avoid further confusion. This will align the conceptual entity name across problem, template, and solution and reduce student mapping burden.
